results.title: Destination Australia: the migrant experience since 1788
results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

results.title: Who'll do the dirty work?
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Destination Australia: the migrant experience since 1788”.
The arrival of more than three million people since World War II has provided a vast labor force. Shows how some of these migrants have struck it rich, but many have been the first to suffer from union neglect and exploitation in low skilled work areas. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

group.title: Destination Australia: the migrant experience since 1788

results.title: The White Australia Policy
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Destination Australia: the migrant experience since 1788”.
Provides a history of Australian working attitudes to non European migration from the first entry restrictions on Chinese in 1885 to the acceptance of Indo-Chinese refugees in the 1970s. This film partoicularly looks at the “White Australia Policy”. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

group.title: Destination Australia: the migrant experience since 1788

results.title: The Widening net 1945-
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Destination Australia: the migrant experience since 1788”.
Covers the period from 1945 to 1985. Shows how the enormous intake of migrants from Britain, Western Europe and the ;Mediterranean alter the face of Australia; and notes how from the early 1970’s, with a changing economy, recruitment fluctuates and then dies down. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: The Golden land: 1840s-1900
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Destination Australia: the migrant experience since 1788”.
This film examines the period of Australian history, 1840-1900, that included the Gold-rush years and the farming boom.

group.title: Destination Australia: the migrant experience since 1788

results.title: Foreigners
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Destination Australia: the migrant experience since 1788”.
One of a series of films that examines the history of immigration to Australia. In this film, “White Australians” give their opinions on the migrant influx, while Irish, Chinese, English and Turkish migrants relate instances of intolerance in Australia. They refer to situations of race, language or cultural difference and of economic pressure. In this film, social commentator Phillip Adams, academic Dinny O’Hearn and (former) RSL President Bruce Ruxton also make comments on matters relating to national identity.

results.title: Design Classic Series
results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

results.title: Barcelona Chair
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Design Classic Series”.
The Barcelona Chair was designed by the great German architect and designer Mies van de Rohe for the German pavilion at the Great Barcelona Exhibition of 1929. Using chrome and leather, he refined the design to the simplest elements of pure form, creating a cult object for those who can afford it.

results.title: The Aga Cooker
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Design Classic Series”.
Created by a blind Swedish designer Dalen in the 1920s, the Aga Cooker has been a symbol of English country life for the last 60 years. Sir Roy Strong, Director of the Victoria and Albert Museum, enthuses about the virtues of the Aga, as does advertising mogul, David Ogilvy, who began his career by selling the “Rolls Royce” of the kitchen, which cooks like a dream and costs like hell!

results.title: Coke Bottle
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Design Classic Series”.
Drink a bottle of Coke and you participate in the American dream. The words of Stephen Bayly, Director of the Conran Foundation epitomise the global system of Western Capitalism. Alex Samuelson’s bottle design won a competition held by the Coca Cola company in 1915.
